child.pub-comments: The two languages grouped together here, Lak and Dargwa, exist in their own subgroups according to Ethnologue.

child.pub-comments: These languages appear beneath Andic and Tsezic subgroups in Ethnologue, with the exception of Avar (ava) which appears beneath a different subgroup, creatively called "Avar."

child.publications: Dryer, Matthew S. 2005. Genealogical Language List. In Bernard Comrie, Matthew S. Dryer, David Gil & Martin Haspelmath (eds.), The World Atlas of Language Structures, 601. New York: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0199255911
child.pub-comments: This subgroup is known as East Caucasian in Ethnologue.

root.publications: Dryer, Matthew S. 2005. Genealogical Language List. In Bernard Comrie, Matthew S. Dryer, David Gil & Martin Haspelmath (eds.), The World Atlas of Language Structures, 601. New York: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0199255911
root.pub-comments:
WALS doesn’t distinguish between languages and dialects, so all lects are called languages, but where Ethnologue considers something a dialect, it has been given a dialect code, and there is a comment. The languages in this tree are found beneath the North Caucasian family in Ethnologue.
WALS Footnote: The two branches of Nakh-Daghestanian, namely Nakh and Daghestanian, are treated as branches of North Caucasion by Ethnologue. While there have been proposals grouping Nakh-Dagestanian and Northwest Caucasian together, the Ethnologue classification is unusual in failing to treat Nakh-Daghestanian as a genealogical grouping.
